Glycemic Index Of Indian Millets

The glycemic index (GI) is a measure of how quickly a food raises blood sugar levels. It is an important tool for managing diabetes and maintaining overall health. In recent years, there has been a growing interest in the glycemic index of Indian millets, as these grains are widely consumed in India and other parts of the world.

Millets are a group of small-seeded grasses that have been cultivated for thousands of years. They are known for their nutritional value and are a staple food in many parts of India. Millets are rich in fiber, protein, vitamins, and minerals, making them a healthy choice for people of all ages.

The glycemic index of a food is determined by how quickly the carbohydrates in that food are broken down and absorbed into the bloodstream. Foods with a high glycemic index are quickly digested and cause a rapid rise in blood sugar levels. On the other hand, foods with a low glycemic index are digested more slowly, resulting in a gradual increase in blood sugar levels.

When it comes to millets, their glycemic index varies depending on the type of millet and how it is prepared. Generally, millets have a low to medium glycemic index, which means they are digested slowly and have a minimal impact on blood sugar levels. This makes them an excellent choice for people with diabetes or those looking to manage their weight.

Let's take a closer look at the glycemic index of some popular Indian millets:

  1. Foxtail Millet: Foxtail millet has a low glycemic index of around 50. It is rich in dietary fiber, which helps in maintaining healthy blood sugar levels. Foxtail millet can be used in a variety of dishes, including upma, pulao, and dosa.

  2. Pearl Millet: Pearl millet, also known as bajra, has a medium glycemic index of around 55. It is a good source of iron, magnesium, and phosphorus. Pearl millet is commonly used to make rotis, porridge, and khichdi.

  3. Finger Millet: Finger millet, also known as ragi, has a low glycemic index of around 50. It is rich in calcium, iron, and amino acids. Finger millet is often used to make dosa, porridge, and rotis.
